author: Dan Allen
title: Pupils defend mum-of-three teacher suspended for posting "provocative" selfie on social media
text:
Lydia Ferguson was suspended after posting the picture on Facebook (Photo: INS News) Share Get daily   
Pupils at a secondary school have jumped to the defence of one of their teachers after she was suspended for posting a "provocative" selfie on social media. 
The teenagers overheard Lydia Ferguson being reprimanded in one of the school's offices before she was escorted from the site. 
The mum-of-three posted a picture of her sitting on the edge of a bed in white dress on Facebook . 
After senior staff discovered the picture, they called Miss Ferguson, who is aged in her 30s, into a meeting. 
Pupils at Ousedale School in Newport Pagnell, near Milton Keynes, Bucks., said they listened as the teacher was accused of being "sultry" and "provocative". Read More The selfie which sparked the row (Photo: Facebook) 
They recorded the eight-minute row on their mobile phones. 
"Miss Ferguson was saying she didn't think there was anything wrong with the photo. All it was showing was a bit of leg," said one pupil. 
The students watched staff subsequently march their teacher off the school premises as she was suspended pending an investigation. 
Pupils have shown their support for Miss Ferguson, who is part of the pastoral care team, and launched a petition called "Get Miss Ferguson Back" as they accused the school of being too prudish. Read More Biology teacher, 27, smiles for her mugshot after turning herself into police over sex allegations with 17-year-old pupil Miss Ferguson is a mum-of-three (Photo: INS News) 
One of them said: "There is nothing wrong with the photo at all. We think Miss looks lovely." 
Another added: "She is a brilliant teacher. She is there to help students who have problems like bullying and stuff. She does so much to help us and we're so upset she's been suspended." 
The petition had more than 250 signatures within just 24 hours of the pupils starting it - with some of signatures coming from parents. 
The picture itself generated more than 300 comments on Facebook but one pupil said: "Not a single person thinks there is anything inappropriate about it." 
Ousedale head teacher Sue Carbert said: "If we have any concerns about a staff member, this would not be discussed with students. We are aware of rumours but conclusions are being drawn which have no factual basis." Like us on Facebook
